titleStmt.title: To WILLIAM JERDAN,William Jerdan (1782-1869; DIctionary of National Biography); 3rd son and 7th child of John Jerdan and Agnes Stuart; his father was a rather easygoing, though respectable, small landowner of Kelso, Roxburghshire. William was editor of the Literary Gazette 1817-50; from 1820 a leading figure in literary society: see Pilgrim Letters 1, p. 207, also Jerdan’s Autobiography (4 vols, 1852-3). 28 JUNE 1841

body.p: Your letter is coming to me, I have no doubt. I am very sorry that I shall not be able to get to Kelso, but I have written my hearty thanks to your brother. See last.

The dinner was a very brilliant affair indeed – they say here, the best on record.The dinner in CD’s honour held at the Waterloo Rooms, Edinburgh, on 25 June: see PIlgrim Letters 2, pp. 310-11 for full annotation. It included all parties and persuasions. They were obliged for lack of room to turn away nearly a hundred applicants for tickets, and besides the diners we had more than a hundred and fifty ladies. Blackwoods are going to publish a good account of the speechifying.In fact they did not do so. When they do, I’ll send you one. Meanwhile I forward you two papers, wherein the reporting is dismal.The Caledonian Mercury gave a brief report and the Edinburgh Evening Courant a slightly fuller one: see ibid., pp. 311-313.
It’s November here. – I hope it may be June in London.
